question:
Babur defeated Mahmud Lodi and Sultan Nusrat Shah thus establishing Mughal rule in India in the Battle of ___________ in 1529.

SSC MTS 04/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The Battle of Ghagra was fought in 1529 between Babur and the combined forces of Mahmud Lodi (brother of Ibrahim Lodi) and Sultan Nusrat Shah of Bengal.
  • Mahmud Lodi, after the defeat of the Lodis in the First Battle of Panipat (1526), tried to reassert Afghan power in Bihar and eastern India.
  • Babur marched east and confronted this alliance at the Ghagra river (near present-day Bihar).
  • Babur decisively defeated the alliance, marking the end of major resistance against Mughal rule in northern India.
  • Thus, the Battle of Ghagra (1529) solidified the foundation of Mughal rule after the earlier victories at Panipat (1526) and Khanwa (1527).

question:
Who among the following Mughal Emperors had assumed the title of Padshah?

SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Mughal emperor Babur assumed the title of Padshah (meaning Emperor or King of Kings) after his decisive victory in the First Battle of Panipat (1526).
  • By adopting this title, Babur projected himself not merely as a regional ruler but as a sovereign ruler of Hindustan.
  • This marked the beginning of the Mughal Empire in India, and Babur's authority was now recognised beyond the military conquest.
  • "Padshah" symbolised imperial authority and distinguished his rule from the previous Delhi Sultanate rulers.

question:
After years of wandering Babur seized Kabul in __________.

SSC MTS 19/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• After facing multiple setbacks in Central Asia, particularly in Samarkand and Fergana, Babur turned his attention towards Afghanistan.
  • In 1504, Babur successfully captured Kabul, which became his base for future operations.
  • This conquest was significant as it provided Babur with a strong strategic position and resources to later launch his campaign into India.
  • From Kabul, Babur consolidated his power and eventually advanced towards the Indian subcontinent, culminating in the Battle of Panipat in 1526.

question:
Which Sultan was defeated by Babur in the first battle of Panipat 1526?

SSC MTS 13/06/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The First Battle of Panipat was fought on 21 April 1526 between Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire, and Ibrahim Lodi, the last Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate from the Lodi dynasty.
  • Ibrahim Lodi had a larger army, but Babur used superior tactics, including the Tulughma system (flanking manoeuvre) and field artillery, which was relatively new in Indian warfare.
  • The result was a decisive victory for Babur, and Ibrahim Lodi was killed in the battle.
  • This victory marked the end of the Delhi Sultanate and the beginning of the Mughal Empire in India.

question:
The famous monument, Aram Bagh, was built by Babur. It is located in ____________.

SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Aram Bagh, also known as the Garden of Rest, was built by Babur in 1528 in Agra, located in Uttar Pradesh.
  • It is considered the oldest Mughal garden in India and was designed in the Persian charbagh style, a quadrilateral layout based on the four gardens of Paradise described in the Quran.
  • Babur was initially buried here temporarily before his remains were later moved to Kabul as per his wishes.
  • The Aram Bagh reflects Babur's fondness for gardens and marks the beginning of Mughal garden architecture in India.

question:
Babur, the first Mughal emperor, succeeded to the throne of Ferghana in ___________ when he was 12 years old.

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire in India, succeeded to the throne of Ferghana (a small principality in present-day Uzbekistan) in the year 1494 at the young age of 12 years.
  • He inherited the kingdom after the death of his father, Umar Shaikh Mirza II, a descendant of Timur (Tamerlane).
  • Despite being young, Babur faced numerous challenges, including internal rebellions and external threats, which shaped his leadership skills early.
  • This marked the beginning of his long journey, eventually leading to his conquest of Delhi in 1526.

question:
Where was Babur buried for the first time in 1530?

Graduate Level 02/08/2022 (Shift-3)
solution:
• Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire, died in 1530 in Agra.
  • After his death, he was initially buried in Agra, which was then the capital of the Mughal Empire.
  • However, as per his own wishes, his remains were later transferred to Kabul, where he was finally reburied in the Bagh-e-Babur (Garden of Babur).
  • This garden in Kabul became his permanent resting place and remains a significant historical site.

question:
Who among the following took the title of 'Ghazi' after defeating Rana Sanga in the Battle of Khanwa in 1527?

SSC MTS 06/07/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• After the First Battle of Panipat (1526), Babur faced strong resistance from Rana Sanga of Mewar who aimed to expel the Mughals from India.
  • The two armies clashed in the Battle of Khanwa in 1527 near present-day Rajasthan.
  • Despite being outnumbered, Babur used superior strategy and artillery, including fortified carts and field guns.
  • Babur decisively defeated Rana Sanga, breaking the Rajput resistance to Mughal rule.
  • After this victory, Babur assumed the title of ‘Ghazi’, which means “warrior of Islam”, to symbolise his triumph over Hindu forces.
  • The title was meant to motivate and religiously legitimise his rule among his largely Muslim troops.
  • This battle confirmed Babur’s control over northern India and further consolidated the Mughal Empire.
  • Babur recorded this victory and the title in his autobiography, the Baburnama.

question:
What was the first name of the Mughal Emperor Babur?

SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The first name or full original name of the Mughal Emperor Babur was Zahiruddin Muhammad Babur.
  • He was born in 1483 in Andijan, in the Fergana Valley (present-day Uzbekistan).
  • "Zahiruddin" means "Defender of the Faith" in Arabic.
  • Babur was a descendant of Timur on his father's side and Genghis Khan on his mother's side.
  • Though his real name was Zahiruddin, he became popularly known as Babur, which means "Tiger" in Persian.
  • The name Babur symbolised his strength and fearlessness as a warrior.
  • He established the Mughal Empire in India after winning the First Battle of Panipat in 1526.
  • His autobiography, Baburnama, offers deep insights into his life and personality.

question:
'Memoirs of Babur' or 'Baburnama', also known as 'Tuzk-e-Babri', was written by:

SSC CHSL 6/8/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The ‘Baburnama’, also known as ‘Tuzk-e-Babri’, is the autobiography of Zahiruddin Muhammad Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire in India.
  • It was originally written by Babur himself in the Chagatai Turkic language, which was his mother tongue.
  • The Baburnama gives a first-hand account of Babur’s life, including his ancestry, military campaigns, political struggles, personal reflections, and observations of nature and society.
  • It is one of the earliest autobiographical works in Islamic and Central Asian literature.
  • The work was later translated into Persian (the court language of the Mughals) during the reign of Emperor Akbar by Abdul Rahim Khan-i-Khanan.
  • Baburnama is noted for its literary style, vivid descriptions, and historical importance.
  • It provides valuable insights into Central Asia, Afghanistan, and India during the early 16th century.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Babur.

question: Babur was originally the ruler of which Central Asian territory before coming to India?
solution:
• Babur was originally the ruler of Fergana, a small principality located in present-day Uzbekistan in Central Asia.
  • He inherited the throne of Fergana in 1494 at the age of 12 after the death of his father, Umar Shaikh Mirza II, a Timurid prince.
  • Fergana was strategically located and was part of the Timurid Empire, established by Babur's ancestor Timur (Tamerlane).
  • Babur’s rule in Fergana faced multiple challenges, including internal rebellions and external threats from rival kingdoms like Bukhara and Samarkand.
  • Although he lost Fergana later, it was from this region that Babur began his military and political journey, which eventually led to the establishment of the Mughal Empire in India.
  • His ambition to reclaim Samarkand shaped many of his early campaigns.
  • Fergana remains significant as Babur’s birthplace and the starting point of his imperial ambitions.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Fergana.

question: Babur was a descendant of Timur from his father’s side and __________ from his mother’s side.
solution:
• Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire in India, had a mixed royal lineage from both his parents.
  • From his father’s side, Babur was a descendant of Timur (Tamerlane), the famous Central Asian conqueror.
  • From his mother’s side, he was a descendant of Chengiz Khan (Genghis Khan), the Mongol ruler who created the largest land empire in history.
  • This dual heritage gave Babur a strong claim to power and legitimacy in both the Turko-Mongol and Islamic traditions.
  • Babur often took pride in his ancestry and mentioned it in his autobiography, the Baburnama.
  • His bloodline also helped him gain support and respect among various tribes and nobles of Central Asia.
  • This heritage of both Timurid and Mongol dynasties made Babur a unique historical figure with deep roots in Central Asian nobility.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Chengiz Khan.

question: The famous autobiography Baburnama was originally written by Babur in which language?
solution:
• The Baburnama, also known as Tuzk-e-Babri, is the autobiography of Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire.
  • It was originally written by Babur himself in the Chagatai Turkish language.
  • Chagatai Turkish was Babur’s mother tongue and the literary language of the Timurid court.
  • The Baburnama is considered one of the first true autobiographies in Islamic literature.
  • It contains detailed accounts of Babur’s life, military campaigns, family, nature, geography, and culture.
  • The text was later translated into Persian, the official language of the Mughal court, during the reign of Emperor Akbar.
  • The Persian translation was done by Abdul Rahim Khan-i-Khanan, one of Akbar’s Navratnas.
  • Hence, the original language of Baburnama is Chagatai Turkish.

question: Which battle marked the beginning of the Mughal Empire in India?
option_2: First Battle of Panipat
solution:
• The First Battle of Panipat, fought on 21 April 1526, marked the beginning of the Mughal Empire in India.
  • It was fought between Babur, a Central Asian ruler, and Ibrahim Lodi, the last Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate (Lodi Dynasty).
  • Despite having a smaller army, Babur used superior military tactics, especially gunpowder artillery and Tulughma (flanking manoeuvre) strategy.
  • Ibrahim Lodi was killed in the battle, and his large army was decisively defeated.
  • This victory gave Babur control over Delhi and Agra, effectively ending the rule of the Delhi Sultanate.
  • It marked the foundation of Mughal rule in India, which lasted for over three centuries.
  • The battle also introduced modern warfare techniques to the Indian subcontinent.
  • Hence, the First Battle of Panipat is considered the starting point of the Mughal Empire.

question: Who was the Afghan ruler defeated by Babur in the First Battle of Panipat (1526)?
solution:
• The First Battle of Panipat was fought on 21 April 1526 between Babur, a Central Asian ruler, and Ibrahim Lodi, the Sultan of Delhi from the Lodi dynasty.
  • Ibrahim Lodi was an Afghan ruler and the last Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate.
  • Babur invaded India with a relatively smaller army but used advanced military tactics like gunpowder artillery and Tulughma (diversion and flanking) strategy.
  • Despite Ibrahim’s much larger force, Babur's tactics proved superior.
  • Ibrahim Lodi was killed in the battle, and his army was completely routed.
  • This defeat marked the end of the Delhi Sultanate and the beginning of the Mughal Empire in India.
  • The battle is regarded as one of the most decisive in Indian history for establishing Mughal rule.
  • Hence, the Afghan ruler defeated by Babur was Ibrahim Lodi.

question: Which powerful Rajput ruler was defeated by Babur in the Battle of Khanwa (1527)?
solution:
• The Battle of Khanwa was fought in 1527 between Babur and the powerful Rajput ruler Rana Sanga of Mewar.
  • Rana Sanga (original name: Rana Sangram Singh) had united several Rajput clans and aimed to drive the Mughals out of India after Babur’s victory at Panipat in 1526.
  • The battle took place near Khanwa, close to Bharatpur in present-day Rajasthan.
  • Rana Sanga had a larger and stronger army, but Babur employed superior tactics, including the use of field artillery and Tulughma formation.
  • Babur declared a Jihad (holy war) against the Rajputs and took the title "Ghazi" after the victory.
  • Rana Sanga was seriously wounded in the battle and later died in 1528, ending Rajput hopes of ousting the Mughals.
  • This battle was crucial in establishing Babur’s firm control over northern India after Panipat.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Rana Sanga.

question: Which military innovation was crucial in Babur’s victory at Panipat?
solution:
• The First Battle of Panipat (1526) marked a turning point in Indian military history due to Babur's use of gunpowder and artillery.
  • Babur introduced field artillery and matchlock guns to the battlefield—technologies that were largely unknown in Indian warfare at the time.
  • He employed Ottoman-style tactics, including cart-mounted cannons (Araba system) and defensive fortifications with wooden carts.
  • These cannons created loud noise and smoke, which terrified the war elephants of Ibrahim Lodi’s army, causing chaos.
  • Babur also utilised the Tulughma strategy, where his forces were divided into flanking columns to encircle the enemy.
  • Despite being outnumbered, Babur’s superior technology and tactics gave him a decisive victory.
  • This innovation marked the beginning of gunpowder warfare in India and laid the foundation of Mughal military dominance.
  • Hence, the key factor in Babur’s victory at Panipat was: Gunpowder and artillery.

question: The Battle of Chanderi in 1528 was fought between Babur and:
solution:
• The Battle of Chanderi was fought in 1528, one year after the Battle of Khanwa (1527).
  • It was fought between Babur, the Mughal emperor, and Medini Rai, a powerful Rajput leader and ally of Rana Sanga.
  • Medini Rai ruled over Chanderi, located in present-day Madhya Pradesh, and resisted Mughal expansion.
  • After defeating Rana Sanga at Khanwa, Babur turned towards Chanderi to crush remaining Rajput resistance.
  • Babur offered Medini Rai the opportunity to surrender, but he refused.
  • The Mughals laid siege to the fort of Chanderi and captured it after a tough fight.
  • Facing defeat, Medini Rai and his followers committed Jauhar and self-sacrifice, a Rajput tradition to avoid capture.
  • This battle symbolised the fall of major Rajput opposition to Babur’s rule in northern and central India.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Medini Rai.

question: Babur defeated the combined forces of Mahmud Lodi and Nusrat Shah of Bengal in which battle?
solution:
• The Battle of Ghaghra was fought in 1529, following Babur’s earlier victories at Panipat (1526) and Khanwa (1527).
  • In this battle, Babur faced a combined alliance of Mahmud Lodi (brother of Ibrahim Lodi) and Sultan Nusrat Shah of Bengal.
  • Mahmud Lodi had fled eastward after the defeat at Panipat and tried to revive Afghan resistance in Bihar with the support of local Afghan chiefs and Bengal's Sultan.
  • The battle took place at the confluence of the Ganga and Ghaghra rivers near present-day Bihar.
  • Babur, with superior tactics and artillery, defeated the joint Afghan-Bengal alliance decisively.
  • This victory marked the end of major organised resistance to Babur’s rule in northern India.
  • It also brought Bihar and parts of Bengal under Mughal influence, further solidifying Mughal power.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Battle of Ghaghra.

question: Babur described India in his memoirs as a land with:
option_1: Clean water and wide roads
option_2: No order or discipline in administration
option_3: No fruits or good people
option_4: Excessive use of coins
solution:
• In his memoirs Baburnama (Tuzk-e-Babri), Babur gave a detailed account of his impressions of India after his conquest.
  • He admired some aspects like the rich land, climate, and wealth, but also criticised the administrative and social systems.
  • Babur specifically mentioned that India had no order or discipline in administration, contrasting it with the well-organised Central Asian governance he was familiar with.
  • He also noted the lack of good infrastructure, such as clean water and roads, and complained about the climate and absence of certain fruits he liked from Central Asia.
  • Despite his criticisms, he recognised India’s potential for empire-building due to its wealth and size.
  • His comments highlight the contrast between Mughal Central Asian traditions and Indian conditions at the time.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: No order or discipline in administration.

question: Who invited Babur to invade India and overthrow Ibrahim Lodi?
option_2: Daulat Khan Lodi and Alam Khan
solution:
• Babur was invited to invade India by Daulat Khan Lodi (Governor of Punjab) and Alam Khan (uncle of Ibrahim Lodi).
  • Both were discontented with Ibrahim Lodi’s rule, which had grown increasingly autocratic and unpopular among Afghan nobles.
  • Daulat Khan Lodi feared losing his position and influence under Ibrahim, while Alam Khan wanted to claim the throne for himself.
  • They sent repeated messages to Babur in Kabul, requesting him to march into India and overthrow Ibrahim Lodi.
  • These invitations gave Babur both a political pretext and local support to justify his invasion.
  • Babur had long aspired to expand into Hindustan, and this opportunity aligned with his ambitions.
  • In 1526, Babur invaded and defeated Ibrahim Lodi in the First Battle of Panipat, establishing the Mughal Empire.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Daulat Khan Lodi and Alam Khan.

question: Babur’s memoirs provide information about which aspects of India?
option_4: All of the above
solution:
• Babur’s memoirs, known as the Baburnama (or Tuzk-e-Babri), provide a rich and detailed account of India during his time.
  • He described the geography of the land, including rivers, mountains, plains, and natural boundaries.
  • He recorded the climate, expressing his dislike for India’s heat and humidity compared to Central Asia.
  • Babur wrote extensively about political conditions, such as the disunity among Indian rulers, weak administration, and internal rivalries (e.g., between Afghan nobles and Ibrahim Lodi).
  • He observed and noted the flora and fauna of India, often comparing them to Central Asian species.
  • The memoirs also include descriptions of agriculture, fruits, festivals, customs, and society.
  • This makes the Baburnama a valuable historical source for understanding 16th-century India.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: All of the above.

question: What title did Babur assume after his victory in the Battle of Khanwa?
solution:
• After his victory in the Battle of Khanwa (1527) against Rana Sanga of Mewar, Babur assumed the title "Ghazi", which means "warrior of Islam".
  • This title was traditionally used for those who had fought and triumphed in a religious war (Jihad) against non-Muslim rulers.
  • Babur declared the battle as a holy war (Jihad) and adopted the title Ghazi to boost the morale of his troops and justify his rule in religious terms.
  • The Battle of Khanwa was significant as it marked the defeat of a powerful Rajput confederacy and cemented Mughal authority in northern India.
  • The victory also helped suppress any further Rajput resistance to Babur's rule.
  • Babur documented this achievement and the title in his memoirs, Baburnama.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Ghazi.

question: The Baburnama is notable for its:
solution:
• The Baburnama, also known as Tuzk-e-Babri, is the autobiography of Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire.
  • It is notable for its neutral and honest tone, where Babur provides first-person accounts of his experiences without excessive glorification.
  • Unlike court chronicles filled with exaggerations, the Baburnama reflects a personal, introspective style.
  • Babur describes his military campaigns, political struggles, natural observations, and personal feelings with clarity and balance.
  • He also mentions his failures and weaknesses, which is rare among royal autobiographies of the time.
  • It includes reflections on geography, flora and fauna, architecture, and administration, but avoids being overly religious or fictional.
  • Because of its neutral, autobiographical tone, the Baburnama stands out as a pioneering work in Islamic and Central Asian literature.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Neutral, autobiographical tone.

question: Which Indian river is frequently mentioned in Babur’s campaigns and battles?
solution:
• The Yamuna River is frequently mentioned in Babur’s campaigns and battles, particularly in the Baburnama.
  • It played a strategic role during his march towards Delhi and Agra after the First Battle of Panipat (1526).
  • Babur crossed the Yamuna during his campaign to confront Rana Sanga at the Battle of Khanwa (1527).
  • The river is also mentioned in the context of military movements, encampments, and logistical planning during Babur's northern Indian campaigns.
  • Yamuna flowed near major Mughal centres like Agra and Delhi, making it crucial to Babur’s expansion.
  • The terrain and water availability near Yamuna were important for Mughal armies.
  • Babur documented the landscape, climate, and riverbanks of the Yamuna with great detail in his memoirs.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Yamuna.

question: Why did Babur face resistance from Rajput rulers even after defeating Ibrahim Lodi?
option_2: Rajputs considered him a foreigner
option_4: His army looted villages
solution:
• Even after Babur defeated Ibrahim Lodi in the First Battle of Panipat (1526) and established Mughal rule, he faced strong resistance from Rajput rulers.
  • The primary reason was that the Rajputs considered Babur a foreign invader who came from Central Asia and did not belong to the traditional Indian ruling class.
  • Rana Sanga of Mewar, in particular, viewed Babur’s rise as a threat to Rajput sovereignty and sought to drive him out of India.
  • The Rajput confederacy was determined to restore Indian rule and prevent long-term foreign domination.
  • Cultural, religious, and political differences further widened the gap between Babur and the Rajputs.
  • This culminated in the Battle of Khanwa (1527) where Babur had to confront the united Rajput forces.
  • The resistance was less about immediate administrative policies and more about identity, legitimacy, and independence.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Rajputs considered him a foreigner.

question: Babur’s victory in the Battle of Ghaghra (1529) helped him:
option_1: Crush the Rajput alliance
option_2: End resistance from Afghan forces in eastern India
solution:
• The Battle of Ghaghra, fought in 1529, was Babur’s final major battle in his Indian campaign.
  • In this battle, Babur defeated the combined forces of Mahmud Lodi (brother of Ibrahim Lodi) and Sultan Nusrat Shah of Bengal.
  • Mahmud Lodi, with support from Afghan nobles, tried to re-establish Afghan power in eastern India, especially in Bihar.
  • Babur's victory at Ghaghra ended the last organised Afghan resistance to Mughal rule in northern and eastern India.
  • It helped consolidate Mughal control over Bihar and extended influence toward Bengal, though Bengal was not fully conquered.
  • This victory followed Babur’s earlier triumphs at Panipat (1526) and Khanwa (1527).
  • The Battle of Ghaghra marked the complete military consolidation of Babur’s rule in North India.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: End resistance from Afghan forces in eastern India.

question: Which art or architectural structure is directly associated with Babur’s personal interest?
option_2: Aram Bagh in Agra
solution:
• The Aram Bagh in Agra is directly associated with Babur’s personal interest in gardens and architecture.
  • Built by Babur in 1528, it was the first Mughal garden in India and reflects the Persian-style charbagh (four-part garden) layout.
  • Babur had a deep love for natural beauty and landscaping, inspired by the gardens of Central Asia.
  • He personally supervised the design and layout of Aram Bagh, making it a symbol of his aesthetic taste.
  • The name “Aram Bagh” means “Garden of Rest”, and Babur was temporarily buried here after his death in 1530 before being moved to Kabul.
  • The garden represents the beginning of Mughal garden architecture in India, which was later expanded by his successors.
  • Other options like Red Fort and Fatehpur Sikri were built by later emperors (Shah Jahan and Akbar respectively), not Babur.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Aram Bagh in Agra.

question: Babur’s army formation at Panipat is considered one of the earliest examples of:
option_2: Use of war elephants
option_3: Tulughma and Araba system
solution:
• At the First Battle of Panipat (1526), Babur employed a revolutionary military formation that involved the Tulughma and Araba system, both of which were unfamiliar in Indian warfare at the time.
  • The Tulughma system involved dividing the army into left, right, and centre units, with additional flanking parties that could encircle the enemy.
  • The Araba system used wooden carts (araba) tied together in rows to form a defensive barricade, behind which Babur positioned cannons and matchlock men.
  • These carts provided protection to the artillery and created choke points for the enemy.
  • This combination allowed Babur’s smaller, well-organised force to defeat the much larger army of Ibrahim Lodi.
  • The strategy showcased Babur’s advanced tactical thinking, influenced by Ottoman and Central Asian military techniques.
  • It marked the beginning of modern warfare in India, with structured formations and use of artillery.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: Tulughma and Araba system.

question: Babur died in which year?
solution:
• Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire in India, died in the year 1530.
  • He passed away on 26 December 1530 in Agra, which was then the capital of the Mughal Empire.
  • At the time of his death, Babur was around 47 years old.
  • His death marked the end of his short but impactful reign (1526–1530) in India.
  • After his death, he was temporarily buried in Agra, and later his remains were moved to Kabul as per his own wish.
  • His son Humayun succeeded him and became the next Mughal Emperor.
  • Babur’s death came just four years after his decisive victory at Panipat, which had established Mughal rule.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: 1530.
